div.p:
Not
a doubt that Lord Mahon
meant to give benefit in
cases like yours to the literary
rather than other commercial
holder of an old copyright
but he neglected to insert
any clause which infers
this effect. The consequence
is that I was forced to
abandone abandon a full half or
nearly so of the advantages
I had anticipated for my
brother-in law, for the extension
of protection for his fathers

works. The bookseller was
firm & I saw he could
not be forced to yield.
In short, you are at the
mercy of the holders of
the stock & of the old
Copyrts Copyrights ; & as Mr Hunter
understands business of this
Kind & on mature consideration
advises you to accept their
offer, I must acquiesce
in the vexatious necessity
It is mortifying but I
think inevitable. No
other bookseller can by

possibility make you any
offer at all. It is only
in case you & yr your actual
Traffickers agree to petition
jointly for the benefit of
the new act, that any
thing whatever can be got
out of the Act for the
behoof of the any holders of
the Edgeworth Copies.
The sum is shabby - but it
is all you are likely to get
if you choose to make the
bargain now. Were Trade
in a better plight, the

people might take a more
liberal view of your claim
as being in better humor
w with
their than own affairs of the
till generally - but it
is only you who can decide
between the propriety of
acting now or of deferring
at the risk which always
belongs to human life.

Since I am writing
I must say I was in hopes
of hearing that you meant
to visit London about this

time. Surely you had given
me some reason for expecting
that great pleasure. Say
it is not to be long deferred.
I consider your silence as
good news about Mrs Wilson
& all the rest of your
house.

My children are very well
- each grown a head since
you saw them, & doing
as I could wish. Sir W.
& Lady Scott too are well
at Bangalore by the last

letters. And of my own
family I have been meeting
, as we must all look
for when years creep on,
w with many afflictions &
not the least truly is thy
melancholy miserable
ending of poor Basil
Hall. He had been
smitten w with palsy in
the Levant & reached
England a month ago in
an alarming condition of
mind as well as of

body. Then came a brief
access of violence - & now
he is a hopeless idiot in
the Haslar hospital at
Portsmouth, hardly ever
recognizing even his devoted
wife when She makes her
daily visit to that
seat of woe! Alas -
Alas -
div.closer:
Ever your affectly
J G Lockhart
